text: hi everyone during the new team Tano
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of this new
polyphia record remember that you will
die this is a brand new LP from Texas
rock outfit polyphia the highly
anticipated follow-up to their new
levels new Devil's record which was
packed with Progressive groovy and
mostly instrumental music with a lot of
stellar and flashy interplay between the
bass drums and guitar with subtle notes
of r b coming through on some of the
Melodies and chord progressions some
electronic music influence coming out of
the Beats some metal influence coming
through on some of the riffs and guitar
tones and of course the more technical
aspects of the band's music makes the
math Rock kids go nuts now while I
didn't love this LP it did have a lot of
fantastic highlights on it and it did
leave me looking forward to whatever the
band was going to do next especially
since they had a few years to kind of
incubate since 2018 and given the
group's Collective talents a follow-up
record uh really could have been
anything stylistically or sonically but
I was kind of disappointed to find that
this new project from them felt sort of
like a watered down take on their
efforts from the last album complete
with some vocal guests who I think were
supposed to help expand the appeal of
the band though I'm not really sure if
that's what ended up happening in
practice like with Sophia Black's cutesy
sped up and warbly refrains throughout
the track ABC ABCDEFG
which just makes me like worry about the
tick tockification of Music uh and and I
don't like that because I don't
typically worry about this sort of thing
because I'm not a [ __ ] Boomer yeah I
imagine this track sounds like hyper pop
to people that find the genre hyper
annoying hideous over processed and
obnoxious there's also kill station
featured on momentum Mori who brings
these really generic emo rap guy vocals
that somehow sound like a toned down Tom
McDonald at points of course that I'm
not really into hearing with with my ear
holes the band sort of scratches a
similar itch with snot on the song [ __ ]
around and find out his flows sadly feel
a bit awkward over this lumbering beat
though I imagine that would be the case
for 99 percent of rappers on this track
and when he does manage to get some flow
momentum or Melody going on the track
you can't even enjoy it because you have
these chirping guitars that are sinking
in with his vocals sort of competing
with his voice in the mix it's like the
band wants to have vocal guests on some
of these tracks but they don't want to
give them the space to really shine like
Lil West for example at the end of
chimera feels absolutely pointless why
is he even on the track if he's not
going to you know play a primary role in
it the most prominent guest on the
entire LP though has to be Chino Moreno
of Deftones Fame on song bloodbath which
just sounds like a poor attempt at a
Deftones song polyphia tries but they
can't quite operate calmly or steadily
enough to really compliment Chino's
voice and it's the solos crushing riffs
and drum fills at the very end of the
track that end up being the best part of
the whole thing the best guests on this
project in my opinion are the fellow
players like anomaly on the track the
audacity which is this amazing Jazz Rock
Cut such a great piece of fusion the
interplay between the guitars bass keys
and drums is just otherworldly really a
show of what the band could be doing if
they were truly trying to push the
envelope and then there's Steve Vai on
the closing track ego death and by no
means am I a VI fan but he fits
perfectly on this polyphia song just
kind of seems like the place for him to
be I guess the grooves and licks and
natural Precision played throughout the
track are just all on 11 plus that Moody
floydian bridge on the track is
fantastic shows how much versatility the
band has in their tool belt when they
want to lean into it really climactic
ending for the track too really
climactic ending for the entire album
there are a few other cuts that I think
could have snugly fit into the new
levels new Devils track list pretty well
be that neurotica or reverie these Cuts
again I think could go Toe to Toe with
any number of songs from that record
you've got the great beats and clean
product action you've got the guitar
work it sounds like rat to tat on crack
but then on top of that there were a few
instrumental risks that I think led to
some mixed results like with the pop
Soul horns that play throughout much of
the song Genesis which I think are kind
of an aesthetic Clash even if they do
make sense with the chord progressions
the band formulated for this cut however
the whistling glitchy edits and thin
Plucky Flamenco inspired guitars
throughout playing God actually go over
really well and while there are many
cuts that I would take over it from new
levels new Devils it's still one of the
better Cuts here and I wouldn't mind
hearing more from the band in this vein
but yeah yeah unfortunately that is this
mixed bag of a record it's a little all
over the place things really do kind of
take a nose dive once we get around
those tracks that have a lot of vocal
guests unfortunately if that's going to
be something the band continues to lean
into with this amount of focus in the
future they're they're going to need to
be pickier about who they bring on and
how they showcase them and figure out a
way to play a more supportive role to
who they are having on an album or
figure out an equation to make them
function within the noodly chaos
surrounding them a bit better and more
sensibly I'm feeling a light to decent
five on this one transition have you
given this album a listen did you love
it did you hate it what would you rate
it you're the best or the best what
should I review next hit the like if you
like Please Subscribe and please don't
cry hit the Bell as well over here next
to my head is another video that you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel Anthony fantano
polyphia album review
forever
